title: How to write a believable female character in a story - Quora

response.answer_text: There is much good information in all these answers but there is one thing I didn’t see (and I may have just missed it) and it is something I think is really important: Examine your own attitudes about and toward women. Look at the culture, beliefs, values, and mores you have grown up with and that you have now. Consider the relationships you have with other women, like your mom, sibs, other family members, friends, & coworkers. Think about female characters in books, movies, etc that you have seen. What do you like, dislike, admire, feel impatient with, etc? All of these things will influence the believeability of your character. I have read many books written by one gender with interesting, fully-realized characters of the opposite gender. Then recently, I picked up a book which was written by a man—a rather prolific writer but not really well-known off the internet—and this book had a female main character. It was awful. His females were simpering idiots who waited around for men to show up and rescue them. Now this would have been fine if that was what he was trying to write—but his characters were supposed to be strong, decisive warrior women and learned mages…after looking at some of his other books, it appears that all of his women seem to defer to men who save them, make decisions for them, and tell them what to do. These females all seem happy with that state of affairs. I read his bio and I have some ideas about where his attitudes may have come from. Thus, my suggestion to you: examine your beliefs and biases so that the only “simpering idiots” (I’m using analogy; maybe you don’t think women are “simpering idiots”) you create in your books are the ones you mean to create.

Well for starters, don’t do this.  For the most part, write female characters the same way you write a believable male character. Women, so I’ve been told, do not go about their days dwelling constantly on being women. Just as you don’t dwell constantly on being a man. They do whatever they do, and think about that. They only think about being women when being a woman specifically matters. Now, since you’re not a woman, for those specific situations, research is your friend. Talk to women you know. Ask them what stands out to them as wrong with poorly written female characters. Ask them what rings particularly true. I’ve written quite a few female characters over the years, and as it happens the majority of my beta readers are women. Supposedly I’m pretty good at writing women. I think for the most part it’s because I don’t actively think about them as women. Given a particular situation, I don’t consider how a woman would respond, I consider how Nadya, Selena, Irina, or Kazya might respond. If being a woman is relevant, I mull it over and figure out what seems reasonable. If I can’t figure it out, I ask women I know what might they do, and use this as a basis for what I write. Don’t be afraid to play to stereotypes, but don’t be bound by them either. Men and women are different. That’s immutable fact. But it doesn’t always matter, and it doesn’t mean that all men are the same or all women are the same. It’s fine to have a character who cares a lot about her appearance. It’s fine to have another that doesn’t. Just…be aware how long makeup takes to put on. I literally polled a bunch of women I know, asking both about time and complexity, because I needed to know for a story I wrote. One of my characters puts a lot of care into her appearance, and when her girlfriend noted that she took a mere fifteen minutes to get ready in the morning, that was an alarm bell that something was off. It also tells experienced readers about how long she usually takes, and the amount of effort she usually puts in. Incidentally I’ve also learned that I’m a big fan of smokey eye and oxblood lipstick on women. The point is, if your character cares about her appearance, it’s not going to be effortless, unless it is and you need to explain why. Magic is a valid answer. If she doesn’t does that make people view her differently? If so, how? Or does it not matter in this culture? Then there are physical differences. It’s fine to have a badass lady who kicks ass. But don’t forget that, barring magic, technology, mutation, or just winning the genetic lottery, she’s going to be smaller and weaker than most men she meets. I addressed this in a story where a lord’s daughter had to learn to swordfight, and her instructor relentless drilled this lesson into her. His solution then was to make sure she was perfectly skilled. Since she could never rely on strength to win the day, she’d have to have perfect form. So she kicks ass by fighting smart, and practicing for hours a day. Finally, don’t forget about mental differences. There’s plenty of research that shows how men and women typically differ in mentality. But the point here is that you shouldn’t have all your women think the same way, or think exactly like all the men. Women tend to write men who emote more than we really do. Men tend to write women who emote more than they really do, or who are stoics just like most of the men. That’s fine for a few specific characters, but realize these should be exceptions, not rules. Don’t be afraid to have a badass who still feels like a woman. Gal Gadot’s Wonder Woman, for example, is both tough as nails and still very feminine. And don’t forget how cultural norms can affect all of this. Your characters are people first, people who happen to be women. And when in doubt, research!  Original question-How do you write a believable female character in a story?
